description: Unknown. Possibly from Old Norse, or a native Old English term. Perhaps somehow from Middle English hote (“to promise, etc.”).

Compare Welsh hoetian (“to dally, dandle”), as well as Scots hoit (“to move awkwardly or clumsily, especially of a stout person or animal, to waddle”), which may be more plausible (especially in sense 2).

entries.meaning: (archaic) To play the fool; to behave thoughtlessly and frivolously.
(obsolete) To leap; to caper; to romp noisily.

verbs.description: hoit (third-person singular simple present hoits, present participle hoiting, simple past and past participle hoit)
